prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Ebonite Feed Heat‑Set

Gloam-glimmer gauzed the ledger-lane;
the vellum mists were velvet-wet.
Through nib-nest nooks the scripples ran—
ebonite feed heat‑set.

“Take care,” croaked Grandscribe, “inkling sprout,
of Blotterwump and Spatterfret!
The Dribble-drake will drip about—
keep ebonite feed heat‑set!”

He took his swiveling scribe-staff up,
his cap-o-clip and tining net;
he stoked the kettle’s hissing cup—
ebonite feed heat‑set.

He warmed the feed till rubber sang,
till fog and fizzle, sultry-sweat;
he pressed the nib and feed as one—
ebonite feed heat‑set.

From Viscus Vale with gluggle-guff
the Dribble-drake, all slop and threat,
came wuff-wuff-wuff with blubbly snuff
and slapped the parchment yet.

“Now hush,” he hissed, “you splutter-snout!”
His tines went flick and silver-flet;
he drew a line so keenly stout—
a ribboned razor jet.

The Dribble-drake un-dribbled then,
its blorple bladders shrank and set;
it folded up its splashes when
the strokes ran true and met.

“O quillsome morn!” the Grandscribe cried,
“O oozy woes, begone and let
the scribble sing, the letters glide—
ebonite feed heat‑set!”

Gloam-glimmer leaves the ledger-lane;
now daylights ink the margins yet.
No blots, no gulps, no glumps remain—
ebonite feed heat‑set.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Hollow Grind on an O1 Blade

’Twas shopglow in the grinder’s lair,
The swarf-sparks flitter-flade;
All nimsy hummed the belt of air,
And quench-tubs sloshly swayed.

“Take heed the Hollowgrind, my sprout—
Its moon-scoops lure and lade!
Beware the chatter-burr about
That chews a newborn blade!

“The Gritling-stones go hummer-hee,
They beck and bevel-braid;
Avoid the Snarl-of-Heat,” said he,
“Where tempers turn to shade.”

He took his O1 steelsome brand,
Ricasso coolly stayed;
With tang and choil in steady hand,
He strode forth unafraid.

He found the stropple-leather tree,
Where paste and tallow played;
He hummed a whetling rhapsody,
And wheeled the hollow blade.

Whiffling through the swarfy murk,
The Hoolyburr down-swayed—
Its raggle chatter, clack and lurk,
Made dullets unarrayed!

One-two! One-two! And whirrle-sheen!
The moon-scoops met their prey;
He snicked the grue from burr to clean,
And stropped the bite away.

He left the wheel with straw-bright grin,
The edge all keenly made;
“O temper-true! O oil within!
O hollow, honed, O1 blade!”

’Twas shopglow in the grinder’s lair,
The swarf-sparks flitter-flade;
All nimsy hummed the belt of air,
And quench-tubs softly swayed.

info.topic: hollow grind on an O1 blade

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Forged Leaf Scroll

When gloamish winds through thwickers blew,
The flindles swirled the knoll;
And glimber-green the bramble grew
About the forged leaf scroll.

"Take heed of Embergnash," said Gran,
"Whose braze-breath chars the bole;
Skirt round the glyphsnake if you can
That guards the leaf-etched scroll."

He shouldered up his quenchblade keen,
And buckled briar-stole;
He whispered wards of salt and green
To shield the story's soul.

Through thistle-thrum and widdershade
He paced with prickle goal;
The letters flittered, shift and fade,
Upon the forged leaf scroll.

At nettle-noon by cinder brook,
The Embergnash did loll;
It flared a grin, a furnace look,
And lunged for leaf-bound scroll.

He raised his blade; it purred and sang
A tempered, silver knell;
Clash-clisk! the starry sparks outrang,
And down the Embergnash fell.

He siphoned up its cinder-breath,
Corked shut the scorchling bowl;
He named the glyphsnake still as death
By rune on leafwise scroll.

Then homeward through the widdershade
He strode with soot and coal;
The elder blinked and bobbed and bade,
"What cheer—and what of scroll?"

He set the bottle, warm and bright,
A glow within a bole;
"Hearth-hush at last; no char tonight—
Read from the forged leaf scroll."

And when the gloamish breezes blue
Go susurring o'er knoll,
The flindles hum, "Aye, all was true,"
Beside the forged leaf scroll.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Conebend

It was kilnish, and the scuddy sherds
Did prickle-fizzle in the shade;
All groggsome were the saggar-wards,
And peepholes ember-made.

“Beware the Conebend, potter-child!
The droop that dooms, the slump that sings!
Beware the Crawlcrawl glaze so wild,
The crazing crackle-wings!”

He took his tongs of temper-bronze;
Long time the peepsight flame he penned;
He rested by the sagger-stones,
To watch the kiln-wind bend.

And as in mullish muffle-heat
He bided by the spyhole’s end,
Came Conebend through the clinker-street,
With wobble-witness blend.

Clip-snap! Slip-snap! the tongstaff flew;
The glazy air went snither-sound;
He set the witness, straight and true,
And felt the fire-moan bound.

He peered and piped a sootish hymn:
“Kiln witness cone bend.”
The drooping tip bowed soft and slim;
“Well-fired,” sang the blend.

Back through the fume he slip-step strode,
With bisque-bright bowls from ember-land;
His steady eyes like coals that glowed,
And steady, steady hand.

It was kilnish; the scuddy sherds
Lay hush in glaze and ash’s braid;
All mildsome were the saggar-wards,
And soot-motes softly played.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Composing Stick

’Twas leaden, and the sluggy sorts
Did clack and cluster in the stick;
All flimsy were the squinty quads,
And quoinish clamps went click.

“Beware the Piedsort, my dear son!
The sorts that slip, the slugs that nip!
Beware the Quibble-Quoin, and shun
The printer’s devil’s grip!”

He primed his composing stick in hand;
Long time the leaden foe he sought—
He lingered by the galley-stand
And proofed awhile his thought.

And as he pondered, kerning-wode,
The Piedsort came with mirror eyes;
It scroodled through the upper case
And mumbled leaden sighs.

Click, clack! Click, clack! and through the stack
The iron stick went stickersmack!
He set it square and spanked it black—
The Piedsort tumbled back.

He left it pied; its letters shed;
He ranged them true from p to q;
He locked the line with quads and lead—
Its motley murmurs through.

“And hast thou quelled the Piedsort? Come,
O typesome lad! Hooray! Hooray!
O proofsome day! Caloo! Calay!”
He chortled, spattered gray.

’Twas leaden, and the sluggy sorts
Did clack and cluster in the stick;
All flimsy were the squinty quads,
And quoinish clamps went click.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Urushi Lacquer Cure

In gloaming gloam the lacquer lay,
All tacksome-thick in humid hoor;
The sap-jars hummed a murmy sway—
Urushi lacquer cure.

“Mind, mopling kin,” the craftmist said,
“Spurn scorchy gales and sunburn lure;
The Nettle-Nick will welt your head—
Seek shade to coax the cure.”

He donned his mask of woven reed,
He primed his brush with sable skure;
With hushful hand and patient heed
He wooed the lacquer cure.

Out skritched the Hurry-Scour with fans,
It flared and fanned in crackly skirr;
“Make haste! Make haste!” its whiffling bans—
“Unstick that waiting cure!”

He raised a tent of mist and cool,
A drapur dome of damp demur;
It thrummed a soft and breathy spool
Around the tender cure.

Drip-drup replied the tree-born gloss,
And night grew deep as raven fur;
It skinned to sheen without a loss—
A moon-dark, midnight cure.

The Hurry-Scour, all crisp and lean,
Unwhirred, unwhuffed, grew wan and blur;
It shrank behind the shadow-green
And left the lacquer cure.

So hum, ye pots, in clouded rooms,
Let patient airs your shine insure;
When dew and time entwine their plumes—
Urushi lacquer cure.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Plum-Brown Blueing Bath

'Twas plum-brown in the blueing bath,
The brimbly bubbles bayed;
All swilky soaps went swarf and swath,
And tubwisped eddies strayed.

"Mind well the Blutherbath," they cried,
"Whose guggle-gowls will gnash!
Beware the Squinch-sop Squirmsnout's slide,
And shun the Brindleplash!"

He gripped his slither-sudden blade,
His scrubber-shield of felt;
By Tap-tap Pipe in steamish shade
He leaned and hummed and dwelt.

And, as he mused in muffled mists,
The Blutherbath came creep—
With slorping lips and bristle wrists,
It slouched in sudsy sweep.

One, two! One, two! Through froth and flume
Went clatter-clash the brand!
He cleft its squush and spouted spume,
He stintled, stark and grand.

He left it limp; he lugged the lump,
The dribbled, draggled head;
He tramply-trudged with sloshing thump
Back up the tiled spread.

"O foamsome joy!" the bathers sang,
"O gladsome, gleamy day!
Now plashy peace may ring and clang—
Huzzah! Halloo! Hooray!"

And plum-brown hums the blueing bath,
Soft lulls the tubbled sea;
The swilky soaps, in swarf and swath,
Now swink in jubilee.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Farewell at a Platform

’Twas twillick, and the clattercars
did shuffle-shunt the shimm’ring steel;
The puffterflies and stoker-stars
went wheeze-a-whirl on wheel and wheel.

“Beware the Long-Goodbye, my heart!
The sniffle-snuff, the clutching clutch;
Beware the Weep-a-start that smart,
the lingerlings that ache too much!”

She tucked her ticket, neat and new,
and snugged her hamper-strap just so;
She leaned upon a pillar-blue,
and let the little sniffles go.

And whiffling through the station-gloom
the Thundertrain came chuff and cheer;
It snorted smoke in cinnamon bloom
and lanterned with a winkish leer.

The pocket-clock went clip and clack,
the whistle raised a whiddle-cry;
They kiss-and-kissed—snick-snack, snick-snack—
then wing-waved wide a wishful bye.

Away, away! the couplers sang,
the carriage-doors went clatter-go;
She watched until the tail-light sank
to cherry-seed and ember-glow.

And twillick, as the clattercars
went hush-a-hum along the rails,
left only lonely luggage-stars
to blink and drip on platform-tiles.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Ink Brayer and Chase

In smudgelight where the sliver sorts
Did skree and scrumble round the forme,
All blottrous were the platen-ports,
And galley-racks did storm.

“Hark for the Ink Brayer, prentice mine—
That brumful roller, slick with dye!
And fear the clacking Chase’s spine,
Its quoinbite nips awry!”

He fetched his trusty quoin-key stout,
His composing stick held true;
He oiled his nerve and ventured out
Through cases cold and blue.

Long time he sought the inky lair
By lamp and letter rain;
He leaned beside the frisket-stair
To settle down his brain.

When, murkily, with rolling drone,
The Ink Brayer blubbed apace;
And clack-clamp-clonk of iron bone—
Behold, the lumbering Chase!

Clip-clap! the quoin-key twined and turned;
His stick flashed quick and keen;
He sprung the frame till wedges burned
And skinned the brayer clean.

He left them locked in formes of night,
Rolled flat as leaden spread;
He proofed the dusk to paper white
And back to Master sped.

“Well done!” cried Master, ink and grin,
“Hoop-hurra, gallant knave!
You set the clampers, pinned them in—
Our shop is brisk and brave!”

In smudgelight now the sliver sorts
Go soft and settle round the forme;
Unblottrous hum the platen-ports,
No galley-rack does storm.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Summit Prayer-Flag

’Twas brashly cold, and the crinkle crags
Did skirl and skree beneath the sky;
All hushsome lay the granite snags,
While whisperwinds went keening by.

“Beware the Galesnap, frostling-bred—
The whupper-wind with raveled wing!
Beware the Tatterwraith,” it said,
“The flitterrag, the flutter-thing!”

He took his chantle-staff in hand,
Long trudged he through the blindle snow;
So rested he by stoneleaf stand,
And hummed his aum so low, so low.

And, as in broodish thought he bent,
The Galesnap, whiffling, sly and spry,
Came skreekling from its tornament
With tangle-teeth and yowly cry!

Thrum-thrum! the chantle-staff went round,
His mantrabell rang chiming clear;
He bound the wind with woven sound
And stitched its shredful shivers near.

O gladsome peak! He leapt the drift,
And laughed amid the shimmer-lag;
He climbed the last white, wobble-lift
And raised the summit prayer-flag.

Now hushly hum the granite snags,
The sky is wide and wintry-high;
The prayer-flag sings in tatty rags,
While whisperwinds go blessing by.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Luthier’s Soundpost Setter

’Twas varnish-hour, and maplebows
Lay dreamling on the bench;
The purfling’s hush and shavings’ soughs
Curled deep in curlèd trench.

“Mind well the Wolftone’s wuther-whinge,
The Buzzy-bumble blare!
Beware the Crackle-Kink that twinge
Beneath the f-holes’ stare!

“Bewatch the Pegbox Pook,” they said,
“That gnaws the singing grain;
And shun the Squallish Skirl that fed
On hollow, boxy rain.”

He took in hand his setter-speer,
A slendersliver’d pick,
With crescent-jaw and tempered jeer,
All bright with clink and click.

Through f-holes’ dusk he slid it in,
Past bridge and bar so stout,
Where spruceheart keeps its secret grin
And maple muses out.

He nudge-and-nestled, tip-to-tip,
He hummed a rosin tune;
The post stood proud with primmish grip,
A sprucepillar in June.

Snick-sneck! the Buzzle blurted off,
The Wolftone lost its paw;
The belly ceased its brattle-cough,
The ribs forgot their gnaw.

Then sprang the strings in chiming cheer—
A thring, a thrumming ring!
From scroll to saddle, far and near,
The box began to sing.

’Twas varnish-hour, and maplebows
Lay dreamling by the light;
The luthier’s setter, mild repose,
Shone small and silver-bright.

<C6_think>Early admonition here is present ("Mind well the Wolftone’s wuther-whinge," "Beware the Crackle-Kink," "Bewatch the Pegbox Pook" with warnings) — clearly present and early in the poem.</C6_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "night‑blooming cereus vigil". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Night‑Blooming Cereus Vigil

By gloam o'clock the cinder skies
went hush and moonward-still;
the candlemoths like sifted rice
were drowsing at the sill.

We kept the night-bloom cereus
along the window seam;
its thorns made soft gramophonic hums,
its ribs like porcelain cream.

We brewed a kettle's candle tea
and wound the tick-tock plate;
we whispered, "Hush! the bud will think—"
and blinked at it to wait.

The gardener-grandsire told it thus:
"At midnight, maybe soon,
it poufs its silken parapluve
and wilts before the noon."

The bud was buttoned tight and pale,
a knuckle of the night;
we heard the crickets knick-knack sing
and gnats in silver light.

Then with a flume of petal-fog
it opened in a hush;
the moonlight made a milk of air,
our cheeks went blossom-blush.

It smelled of somewhere never-seen—
a rainclock, starbread moon;
like night-baked sugar on the fence,
like lanterns steeped in moon.

The beetles doffed their pewter hats,
the moths began to croon;
the lizard in his livery
stood blinking like a spoon.

We spun our watch to wobble slow,
we let the minutes swoon;
the cereus whispered whither-where
and drank the hollow moon.

At cockcrow-creak the petals yawned
and felt their silk unweave;
they folded up their whitedream wings
and drifted into sleeve.

O hushsome bloom! O secret night!
O watch that learned to grieve—
for loveliness that blooms so bright
and leaves before we leave.

Yet set again our teacup-guard,
our candle's thimble-flame;
whenever summer's murmurmoth
comes whispering the same.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "modular synth patch spaghetti". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Modular Synth Patch Spaghetti

At tickle-tock the LEDs
went twittle-wink and glowly-getty;
Through sockets, jacks, and jellied reeds
there sprawled a patch of long spaghetti.

The squirmy leads went squizzle-swish,
the clock went clack, the gate held steady;
LFOs did wobble-fish
beneath the noodles, wet and weddy.

“Take heed,” hummed some phantom note,
“the Tanglewump grows wild and sweaty;
It chews your mix and knots your throat—
beware the snarl of rack spaghetti.”

He gripped his jacks with knightly poise,
his mults and menders neat and netty;
He whispered to the burbling noise
and faced the writhing patch spaghetti.

Zip-zap! Zip-zap! Through send and thru
he swapped the gates from mess to metty;
He quantized chaos, clocked the brew,
and phased the beast to 4/4 steady.

He slewed the slew, he trimmed the tune,
he set the cutoff calm and ready;
He ducked the feedback’s howling moon
and bridled resonance too heady.

At last the waveform softly purred,
a bleeble beat, a bubbly jetty;
The noodles coiled like dreaming birds—
no longer wrath, just tame spaghetti.

At afterglow the LED
went wink-a-wink, all warm and petty;
The racklet hummed contentedly
through modular synth patch spaghetti.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "cassette wow and flutter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cassetterwock

At hiss o'clock the spooly reels
Went warble-wob through plastic pane;
All ferric-brown the ribbon peals,
And pinchling rollers strain and strain.

Beware Cassetterwock, my sprout!
The crimble jaws, the crinkle bite!
Beware the Wow-and-Flutter Lout,
The capstan's clutch at darkling night!

Take up thy demag-wand, be keen,
Set azimuth to truest sight;
The Dolby-mask and Splicer-sheen—
Go forth and set it right, now bright.

In Warblewood he lazed a while,
By leader-tape and socket-slot;
He hummed a hum in capstan style,
And wistful wows were quite forgot.

And, as in musings muff and mum,
Cassetterwock, with flutty yaw,
Came fluster-flutter, rattle-rum,
And wowed with gummy-gloomy maw!

Snit-snat! the Splicer-sheen did slice,
He snagged the tape from tangly throat;
He pinched the reels with steady vise,
And stilled the warbly note at last.

Back jigged he through the hisssome air,
Demag-wand warm with triumph's glow;
O tape-true day! O sauber fair!
They cried along the deckland row.

Tamed you Cassetterwock, my bean?
Come press and press; play, pause, rewind!
He laughed a laugh all clickless-clean,
No flutter-furtling left behind.

Now hush o'clock, the cassette reels
Go smooth-and-steady round the case;
How silken-true the ribbon feels,
And songs sit right again in place.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "opal play‑of‑color flash". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Opal Play-of-Color Flash

In twilglow, the slivery sheens
Went wizzle-wob through gloam,
And plashy pods in prismic greens
Beflittered all the loam;
The choral-coals of rainbows winked
Through dribbled drusy ash—
Hark how the opal heartlight blinked:
The play-of-color flash!

Old-whispered warnings snick and nick:
The Opalfash that flares,
The irid-surge, the dazzleflick
That gulps at gawking stares;
Steer wide of glimmercorridors
Where prism-winds go swash—
For sudden, sly, and starry-slick,
The play-of-color flash.

He gripped his shimmerbraidish brand,
He cinched his prancer sash;
He trailed the ripples rainbow-tinged
And heard the fizzle-smash.
Through wobbled woods and whorled weirs
He jinked on tipple-toe,
Where moonlets made a marbling rain
And opal-embers snow.

Out sprang the Play-of-Color Beast,
With eyes like fretted glass,
Its frills a fraying thunderclout,
Its throat a mirror mass;
It yowled in many tinsel tongues,
It flurried, flared, and flashed—
It milled the night to confetti light
And giggled as it crashed.

They circled in the prism-mist;
The air went spangle-spry,
He feinted left with flicker-feet
And leapt a tinsel-cry;
His shimmerbrand went chirr-chirr-churr,
A fireflying slash—
He split the glare from gullet’s glare:
Kerfizzle, flimmer, shash!

The creature coughed up candle-rain
And folded like a fan,
Its sparkles drained to puddled plain
Of chalk and shadow-sand;
The world unwhirled from dazzle-dream,
The color-rills abashed—
And into hush the echoes mushed
Of play-of-color flash.

He bore the cooled kaleido-core
In net of knotty thatch,
Came stamping through the gloaming lanes
With trophy opal-swatch;
The hearthbells bonged, the neighbors thronged
In mittens, cap, and sash—
“O twindle-time! Hooriddle-chime!”
They trilled in hoppish thrash.

In twilglow, the slivery sheens
Still wizzle-wob through gloam,
And sleeping pods in prismic greens
Lie lamped along the loam;
The choral-coals now emberwink
In peace within the ash—
Yet somewhere, sly, the moon-milk blinks:
The play-of-color flash.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Peony Ants at Dawn

Rimpled the hush where day begins,
And rosings fizzed the yew;
The petal-crumbs on velvet chins
Wore beads of brimming dew.

The peony ants came click-a-clack
In rankled ruby line;
With sugar-knapsacks on their back
And whiskers tipped with shine.

"Mind, little leaf," the elder said,
"These dawnish drummers tread;
They pilfer pink from budding bed
And sip the morning’s thread.

They skitter-sweep the garden’s grin,
They tidily untwine
The knotty knots the night leaves in
The skein of blossom-time."

I crouched beside the blushing bowl,
My breath a mousy breeze,
And watched their minute kettles roll
Through ruffled rosaries.

Up chimed a bell of pollen-brass;
A queenlet, musk and small,
Came velure-sailed; the ranks, en masse,
Went hush and heeded all.

They braided light with amber lace,
They mended dawn askew;
They buttoned up the petal-face
With drops of melted dew.

And when the sun went loud and wide,
They dwindled rootward drawn;
Yet still my ear can hear their stride—
O peony ants at dawn!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Civet Note and Drydown

’Twas muskish dusk; the snifter-loons
Went swirl and skirl through parlor gloom;
Citrusquills and peppertunes
Made topnotes prance and ploom.

“Beware the civet note, my nose—
That velvet-feral purr and pang!
And shun the drowsing drydown’s doze,
Where resin-shadows hang!”

He primed his vapor-sabre bright;
He sniffed his courage ounce by ounce.
Long while he stalked the amber night—
At labdan-stump he flounced.

And, as in snuffling thought he stood,
The Civet Note, all sleek and sly,
Came purring through the chypre-wood
With moonish, glimmer-eye.

Spritz-spritz! Hush-hush! Through musk and mass
The vaporsabre zither-zoomed;
He split its purr from amber-glass,
And stilled the beast perfumed.

He bore its tuft of shadowed musk
And laughed a nutmeg-merry cheer:
“O bless my snout, this zany dusk!
The flasks all dance, my dear!”

A tale of civet note and drydown deep—
Of bright begin and duskings keep;
Where topnote sings and basenote sleeps
In dreamsome, spiral sweep.

Now hush—the drydown slow unspools:
Soft sandal, tonka, nard and gown;
The rivery sillage dims and cools,
And settles noseward down.

’Tis muskish mild; the snifter-loons
No longer skirl about the room;
The civet stilled in cedar runes,
And dreams make amber bloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Reglet and Furniture

'Twas copytime; the sluggy sorts
went clitter-clatter through the chase;
The galleys gloomed in greasy courts,
and sullen quoins lost place.

Beware the Furnidrake, my sprout—
the teeth that jam, the clamps that crunch!
And keep the fretful Furniture out,
the skittering Reglet-bunch!

He raised his trusty composing stick;
long while the pieful foe he sought—
he leaned beside the platen-brick
and stood in inkish thought.

And, as in inkish thought he stood,
the Furnidrake, with lids of lead,
came clanking through the furniture wood,
ker-thudding as it sped.

Click-clack! Click-clack! Through quads and rack,
the reglet-rod went ticker-tack!
It split the clamps with clatt'ring crack,
and galley-galloped back.

"Hast felled the Furnidrake at last?
Come to my arms, my beam-bright lad!
O kerning days returned from past!"
the master pressman gladness had.

'Tis copytime; the sluggy sorts
go clitter-clatter in the chase;
The galleys preen in leaden forts,
and Reglet, Furniture, keep place.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Old Piton Scar

'Twas craglight, and the scree-worn boots
Did scritch and skreel along the bar;
All chossy were the shale-strewn routes,
Beside the hoary Piton-Scar.

Shun the old Piton-Scar, young sprig;
The crackclaw winds wake up at night!
Eschew the rusted Rattler-rig,
And mind the Snapjaw Cams that bite!

He baled his rope and chalked his mitts;
His quickdraws clinked like rattla-tin;
He stalked the Scar by crabwise fits,
With granite-stead and stony grin.

He perched beside a Rumble-root,
Where alpen-goblins peep and purr;
He sipped a breath of cold to boot,
And held his heart from stir and whir.

And, burbling up the basalt seam,
Came the Old Piton-Scar in glare;
Its boltless grin, a rust-red gleam,
Its breath a gritstone blare laid bare.

He met it mid the mizzle-muck—
Clink-clatter went his steely pack;
He drove his pick with sparrow-luck,
And cleft it crack from crack to black.

"Old Piton-Scar is down?" he cried;
"O summit-glee! Huroo! Hurray!
Come, prance and pound the pitons, pride,
And dine on scree and spray today!"

'Twas craglight, and the scree-worn boots
Did scritch and skreel along the bar;
All chossy were the shale-strewn routes,
Beside the hoary Piton-Scar.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Loomshuttle Pick

'Twas selvedge-time, and twistful threads
Did shiver-shank along the beam;
All ravelry the heddle-beds,
And slubworts frayed the seam.

"Beware the Loomshuttle Pick, my kit!
The ratchet-gnash! the shuttle-skim!
Beware the snaggle-snatch of it,
The warp-wight, grim of limb!"

He took his snipshear sabre keen,
His beater-blade of tempered steel;
Long time the selverswath, unseen,
He trod by bobbin-bog and reel.

And as in twistsome thought he stood,
With whorl-wind whistling through the shed,
Came slinking through the warpwood hood
The Pick with eyes of thread.

Snip-snap! it nipped, and thrum-thrum! clacked
Its shuttle-wings and ratchet-beak;
He countered—whap! the beater smacked—
A weftwild, whirring shriek!

He looped it in a selve-knot snare,
He cleft its nap with shearing click;
He bore the spoolish head to lair—
O spoolsome day! hurrah, hurick!

"And hast thou unpicked the Loomshuttle Pick?
Come, clap thy hands, my spindle-son!
Now dance the loom, shuttle, pick!
Our weaving war is won!"

'Twas selvedge-time, and twistful threads
Went swive-and-shim along the beam;
All ravelry the heddle-beds,
And peace lay in the seam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "tinsmith stake song". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tinsmith’s Stake-Song

In glimble dusk the rivets rang,
and snicket winds blew long;
The pannikin pines went pang-a-pang
to the tinsmith’s stake-song.

The snarfle-sparks were shim and sheer,
the gutters glowed with braze;
While solder-moons slid gear to gear,
through flitter-iron haze.

“Clamp close thy knuckles, copper-kin,
keep keen thy snipping blade;
For clatterwraths creep tin-on-tin
where shadow seams are laid.”

He gripped his mallet, stub and spry,
his stake a stoutling cone;
And hummed the measure, ding and die,
through plate and pewter bone.

Then slouched the Gutter-Grindlegrim,
with jaw like jagged tongs;
Its belly beat a brassy hymn
of skreaking, scalded gongs.

Crick-crack! went shear and counter-swing,
smelt-scent and spatter-sheen;
The tinsmith turned a twyfold ring
and trimmed the wrangle clean.

“Ha! harken now, you rivet-wight,”
he laughed in clinks and chime,
“My stake-song’s set to cut the night
in quarter-beats of time.”

They whurled a while in whittle-drift,
till snarl gave out a sigh;
He peened the beast with peen and lift
and let its rattles lie.

Back through the yawl of alley-yards,
past pails and panniers long,
He came with calm of canting shards
and the tinsmith’s stake-song.

O clink-a-day, O brazen gleam!
O snug and solder-strong!
The gutters grin, the kettles dream
to the tinsmith’s stake-song.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pietra dura inlay". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pietra-Dura Lay

In marble-murmur twilight halls,
Where agate-shadowed silence falls,
The bevel-breezes brush and sway
Through pietra dura inlay.

Mind well the groutling Gravnagrin,
With chisel-chuckle, granite grin;
The filigruff, the tessel-fox,
And clackstone-bellied morter-ox.

He wreathed his opal-etching blade,
His jasper-guard, his onyx spade;
He muttered runes of set and stay,
And sought the inlaid maze’s grey.

Through lapis-lantern corridors
Past alabaster-cindered doors,
He paced where tile and tint entwine,
By serpentine and tourmaline.

Then from the mosaic’s moody seam
A quarry-quickened shape did stream:
The Gravnagrin with quartzicle eyes,
And mortar-breath and marble sighs.

It clattered, clove the chamfer air,
With clink and clunk and calcin flare;
He parried—chip!—and cross-grain sprang,
The opal-edge went snither-slang.

Down fell the groutling, cleft and still;
Its tessers slicked the checkered sill.
He bore the head by mallet’s brace
Back through the patterned-gleaming place.

O joyous jade! O carnel cheer!
Ring, lapidary laughter, here!
Come, curl and carol, dance the day,
In pietra dura bright array.

And still the bevel breezes roam,
Past agate arches, opaled foam;
While, polished-clean of fang and fray,
The inlaid walls gleam mild and gay.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Blue Hour on Snow

It was cobalt-hush; the snithered snows
Did twirl and tundle through the dale:
All glimmershade the firwood froze,
And moonlets thimble-pale.

“Beware the Bluehour-beast, sweet sprout,
So velvet, slow, and low!
Beware the slumbrous Snuffleglout,
And shun the Muzzlemowe!”

He gripped an icekeen winterbrand,
His mufflemask and scrip;
Long sought he out the hushsome land,
By drift and frostnip-hip.

He stood beside a drumble bank
Where wind had swaled it thin;
He leaned in thinkings, faint and frank,
And let the blue begin—

When swooning through the duskward pines
The Bluehour came asnow:
It murbled in the powder-shines
And sighed a glassy glow.

Up swung his frostbright ferrule-sword—
Skrit-skrat! the silence split;
He snicked the dusk in ribboned shard
And cleaved the winter’s knit.

He corked the hush in crystal phial,
The gloam within its glass,
Then home he tramped a lamplit mile
Across the glintered pass.

“O snowy-sweet! O bonny blue!”
Cried elder, cap aslant.
“To snare the hour and bring it true—
What brave and blue-bright cant!”

It was cobalt-hush; the snithered snows
Still twirled and tundled low:
All glimmershade the firwood froze,
In blue hour on snow.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "crosstie creosote scent". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Crosstie Creosote Scent

Gloamtime the switchyard simmered slow;
the ballast-grit went scrinch and shent.
Gandy-lings in sideling row
breathed crosstie creosote scent.

“Mind now the Reekaroo,” said Pop,
the Nailcap-gnome with gloves of dent;
“It gulps the tar from tie to top
and fattens on the scent.”

He took his spike-maul sabrelong,
his lamp a lucent filament;
He tramped the track in clickclick song
through crosstie creosote scent.

Out from the fog the Reekaroo,
with snoot a dribble-black intent,
came whuffing up in tarry mew
and wallowed in the scent.

Clack-twang! the spike-maul smote the night;
it boomed and burred and downward bent.
The Reekaroo uncoiled its blight—
fell still amid the scent.

“Ah, soot-sung eve!” the Nailcap crowed,
“Your knurl and nerve were bravely spent!”
They clinked their mugs and homeward strode
through crosstie creosote scent.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Balance Spring Collet

When gearlight swam through oaken panes,
and mainsprouts hummed and shivered,
I wandered down the spindle lanes
where pinionlings all quivered.

"Hold close thy gloves," the clocksmith pled,
"It snaps as quick as shuts a wallet;
that twiny thing with copper head—
the balance spring collet."

I took my loupe and tweezer-keen
and slipped my thumb-guard wallet;
through escapelanes of brass and green
I sought the springish collet.

It coiled along a pivot-stem,
a clamp with eyes of onyx;
its biting ring a tiny hem
that tuned the spring's harmonics.

Tick-tacket went my beating heart,
the screws made hush to stall it;
I pinched—so neat!—with surgeon art,
and wrangled that sly collet.

It sprang and spun a corkscrew path,
and clacked its tiny palette;
I held it fast despite its wrath,
that stubborn, brassy collet.

"Now set it true and set it tight!"
the old clock-keeper called it;
and time went dancing into light,
tamed by the balanced collet.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Pantograph Arcing Blue

At gloam-o'clock the tramling runs,
Through cindermist and dew;
The sky is strung with zither-lines,
Pantograph arcing blue.

The catenairy cobweb sings,
A hiss, a kiss, a phew;
The shoelet skips the copper's lip—
A sparkbird skreels it through.

Mind all the switch-grimps in the gorse,
The bogon at the clew;
They nibble at the nightward rails
And chew the sleepers skew.

On trundled, tramulous, the car,
Its windows whistled true;
The overhead, in filigree,
Wrote runes of zizzle-glue.

Up leapt the panto-grappling arm,
A whisker, quick and shrew;
It skitted from the wire’s skin—
A blurt of arcing blue.

Then hush! the sparksnip faded small,
The shoe was snug anew;
The town unlatched its moonward mouth
To drink the fizzling view.

So swirl your journeys, gentle wheels,
Through cindermist and dew;
Let sky-wires purr their silver purrs—
Pantograph, arcing blue.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration Over Stubble

At tawny edge the harvest lea,
All nubbled with its nipped-down stubble,
The thistle-snags stood bristly-free—
And burrs went whisk, a whisper-rubble.

Hark to the murmur-cloud that swirls,
A sootflock binding dusk to double;
It laces wind in loops and twirls—
Murmuration over stubble.

A stripling by the rimpled hedge
Held fast his muffler, meek and mubble;
He craned to see the soot-feathered surge
Go sibble-sabble, strow and bubble.

They flither, flather, weave and wheel,
A creeling night in brimful trouble;
They knot the sky on spindle-steel—
Murmuration over stubble.

They selch and swerve; they billow-bend;
They quirk the cold, they quail and double;
A dragon’s spine, a tatter’s end—
Then seed to speck and burst to bubble.

A hush went lisking through the hay;
The old crows coughed a croaky hubble;
The very moon forgot her way—
For all that whirling, whisper-trouble.

And when the black-silk flock unspooled,
Like soot-snow blown from chimney-scuttle,
The field lay star-pricked, meek and cooled,
Its shadow-motes all shy and subtle.

At tawny edge the harvest lea,
Where nubbly stems stand staid and stubble,
The wind keeps tale in loops of three—
Of murmurs nested under stubble.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Pewter Inlay Ribbon

At gloam-o’-clock the slither-rills
went skreeling through the bramblebrae;
and mummer-mites with whisper-gills
prickle-prankled down the way.

Mind, sprig-of-moss: that pewter inlay ribbon—
its fret and filigree are sly;
it loops the loosey wit within
and tethers egret-thoughts that fly.

I found it coiled on shingle-stone
beneath a tuft of nettle-hair;
it chimed like rain on kettlebone
and smelled of tin and thimble air.

Then up from bog and tatter-reed
the Ravelgnash came snuff and sneer—
with lantern-teeth and bracken-beard,
it made the cattail shadows leer.

I cast the pewter inlay ribbon,
I sang the knots in click and rhyme;
around its skulking ankle-sinew
the silver loopled, slick with time.

It dwindled down to rumble-pebbles,
to flecks of soot and wintry grin;
the ribbon purred in subtle trebles
and stitched the hedgerows rim to rim.

So still the slither-rills go by,
less skreel, more lull, in bramblebrae;
and if you hear a metal sigh,
step soft—let silver keep its way.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Linocut Brayer Chatter

When lino-lamps lay lucid-low,
and brayers mumbled patter,
The burly blocks in burrowed row
made linocut brayer chatter.

The studio sprites went nip and nudge,
ink-otters slicked and slather;
Mind how the Gougegrin keeps a grudge
and snicks your thumbs to lather!

He palmed his baren, burnish-round,
his V-gouge keen as matter;
He rolled the roller, slicking sound—
a syrupy, sooty spatter.

Out through the paper-forest thin,
with tack-a-tack-a clatter,
There lumbered up the Brayergrin—
its rubber ribs went patter.

It whuffled, wheeled from tray to tray,
its tacky whiskers spatter;
He squared the block to still its sway
and quelled the gummy chatter.

Press-press! he pressed, then peeled the sheet—
oh hush, the studio clatter!—
The Brayergrin lay crisp and neat,
a shadow, proof, and splatter.

"Hurro! Hurrip!" the printlings cried,
"the ghosting’s gone to tatters!"
He twirled his proof with inky pride
and laughed in lino-lathers.

When lino-lamps lay lucid-low,
and brayers mumbled patter,
The burly blocks in burrowed row
made linocut brayer chatter.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quarter‑sawn shimmer". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quarter‑Sawn Shimmer

Hushlight hovered; the mill-lamps loomed,
The kerfs went whirry‑whirr and thin;
All quarter‑sawn the planks perfumed,
And fleckfire flittered in.

“Beware the Quarter‑Sawn Shimmer, lad—
The fleckfang flare, the ray‑flit catch!
Beware the clacksome Jointer‑jad,
And shun the Bevelsnatch!”

He shouldered up his froe and square,
His mallet‑heart was steady‑brave;
Long while he stalked the whorl‑bent air
Along the sawdust nave.

While knotwise lost in thinking there,
The Shimmer slid from grainy gloom;
It swarfled through the quartered ware
And silvered out the room.

Clip‑clop! Thrum‑thrum! through fleck and flume,
The froe‑blade bit with snick‑and‑crack;
He quenched its glint; with captured bloom
He lugged the Shimmer back.

“And hast thou stilled its glimmering?
Come here, my clever timber‑boy!
O beamlit day! Hooray within!”
He laughed a sawdust joy.

Then hushlight lingered; the mill‑lamps dimmed,
The kerfs fell still and true and thin;
All quarter‑sawn the boards were trimmed,
And fleckfire slept within.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Blued Screw in a Movement

At tickletide the slinky cogs
Did flurry-furl in case and crown;
All fumble-brass were gearling bogs,
And whisker-springs wound down.

Take heed the blued screw in a movement bright,
Its azure bite, its tempered gleam!
It grips the balant wheel so tight—
Unloosed, it spills the dream.

He took his pinset long and lean,
His tweezerblade of patent make;
He sought the burble-plates between
Where timelings hum and quake.

There whorled a whizzing winker-gnurl,
Blue-burnished, bold and stithy-true;
It sang a clicksong whirl-on-whirl—
The very bluedsome screw!

He set the slot with steady art,
And skritch-skrach went the driver wand;
The mainspring bristled, leapt apart,
Then settled, cool and fond.

Ticktockery burst bright and brave,
The balancer began to prance;
Through jewel-pools the oillets waved,
The hands took up the dance.

"O timesome joy!" the watchsmith cried,
"O brabble-bright! O merry tune!
You’ve set the heart within its hide—
It keeps the afternoon!"

At tickletide the slinky cogs
Still flurry-furl in case and crown;
No longer limp the gearling bogs—
The whisker-springs wind down.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Parrel Bead on a Gaff

In scudsome gloam the scuttlewinds
went snickering through the stave;
the ratlines hummed their tarry hymns,
the bulwarks bowed to wave.

“Beware the Gaffergrim, my sprout,
and jibbering Boom-a-bite!
Bewatch the slewing swingabout,
the clewclaws keen and white!”

He took his marline-sparkling blade,
his belay-pin of oak;
he reefed his courage, knot on braid,
and stuffed his fears with smoke.

Long by the shrouds he scoused and scanned,
where gullish vapors quaff;
and click! there came, as fate had planned,
parrel bead on a gaff.

It skirred along the wobble-spar,
the dreaded Gaffergrim;
it sniffed the salt from near and far
and gnashed a briny hymn.

Snap went the block, the boom did yaw,
he stood his ground and laughed;
he sprang the trap with tarry paw—
parrel bead on a gaff!

He smote it thrice with belay-pin
and twice with marline blade;
the Gaffergrim fell slack therein,
its snarl unrigged and splayed.

“O brabble-bright!” the bosun cried,
“O huzza! hail the day!
Now furl thy dread and step in pride—
heave-ho the gloom away!”

And still when scudsome gloams unhinge
and shanty-sighs are grave,
the ratlines croon along the fringe
of parrel bead on a gaff.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sourdough levain autolyse". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sourdough Levain Autolyse

'Twas leaventide, and slurry loams
did stretch-and-fold in mixing seas;
All tacky were the gluten domes,
and flour fogged the breeze.

"Beware Hastlebake, my rising child!
The gummy crumb, the pallid slice!
Beware the Whirr-Kneederling wild,
but trust the autolyse!"

He took his lively levain up—
long time the water-scale he eyed;
He let the thirsty flours sup,
and left them all to bide.

When Stodgebread, with steamless stare,
came slumping from the underproof,
it burbled blandly, dense as air,
and clung in gloopish roof.

Flip-flap! With foldings, soft and nice,
he coaxed it round in levain light;
The autolyse sang cool as ice
and set the lattice right.

Zip-zap! the lame went snickle-scrack—
a grigne awoke; two ears took shape;
He steamed the stone; the oven, black,
boom-roared: "Sourdough-spring!" agape.

"And hast thou trounced the Denselump?
O crumbtious day! Hoo-ray! Hoo-rise!"
He tapped the loaf with jigsome thump
and laughed with tangwise eyes.

'Twas leaventide; the slurry loams
still stretch-and-fold in mixing seas;
All golden hum the gluten domes,
and levain scents the breeze.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sashiko boro patch". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sashiko Boro Patch

It stitchened dusk; the frayish flocks
did twill and twirl upon the sash;
All rimpled rags and raggle-locks,
and indigo with moonlit flash.

"Mind you the Boro-Patch, dear heart—
the needle-nips and snaglines catch;
Skirt tatter-ghouls that pull apart,
and shun the frowsy Ravel-Thatch!"

I primed my palm with running thread,
a milk-white river on the blue;
I hummed the counts of stitchy tread,
till seams remembered all they knew.

And as I stooped by selvedge seam,
there scruffled up, all scritch and scratch,
a ruffle-wraith from denim’s dream—
the snarl-boned, bristly Ravelwretch!

Quick flew the thread in running rows,
the needle clicked a tikker-tatch;
Across the warp where denim grows,
I bound and buckled ravelratch.

Heigh-hem, I sang with thimble-thumb!
The tatters tamed, the textures match;
I danced the darning, drum-a-drum,
and raised my sashiko boro patch.

It stitchened eve; the frayish flocks
now twill in peace along the sash;
All rimpled rags and raggle-locks
lie smooth beneath the moonlight’s wash.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nixie tube warm glow". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Nixie Tube Warm Glow

In duskward hush the benches gleamed,
And vacuum-ghosts were set to flow;
The digit-sprites all amber-dreamed
In nixie tube warm glow.

“Beware the Neonix, my child!
The cathode-fang, the anode-claw!
Beware the fizzlephant so wild,
The tickertock that gnaw!”

He took his solder-burnished blade,
His pliers keen, his spanner true;
He sought the Vacu-Umber shade
By buzzing avenues.

Long time he traced the circuit lanes,
Where loomy coils made raster-bow;
He paused within the vacuum vanes
And heard a sizzle rising low—

And hark! The Neonix, alight,
Came zizzing through the wire-wood;
Its digits clicked a burning bright,
Its beak of numbers stood.

Zik-zak! Zik-zak! The cutter clapped,
The solder-sparks did leap and go;
He parried fast, he lunged and tapped—
It winked to naught below.

“And hast thou stilled the Neonix?
Come to my arm, O valiant tot!
O lumen-lovely joy of ticks—
Huzzah, what triumph got!”

In duskward hush the benches gleamed,
And vacuum-ghosts were set to flow;
The digit-sprites once more they dreamed
In nixie tube warm glow.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fishtail gouge sweep". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Fishtail Gouge Sweep

When benchlight honeyed over oak
and curls began to creep,
The mallet-moths went thrum and stroke—
fishtail gouge sweep.

The grainwind whispered hush-a-while,
the strop sang stroam and lee;
In sprocket-scent of linseed oil
the chips went skirl and spree.

"Mind Splintergrim," the joiner said,
"and Knotling's snag-toothed reeve;
Shun Burlikink and Snipe-a-thread
that tear where fibers cleave.

"Their burrs are wicked, wild with grit,
their whiskers rasp and weep;
They dwell in boards not seasoned yet—"
fishtail gouge sweep.

He took his fishtail, Sweep Eleven,
his bevel bright and steep,
His mallet called a maple heaven—
tick-tock, tap-tip, teep.

He marked the run of wintergrain,
he felt the summer's sweep;
He set the knife to cedar's vein—
skirr-scritch, skirrup, seep.

And as he leaned by shavings trough
where curlings mound and heap,
The Splintergrim unshouldered off
the heartwood's knotted keep.

It shambled out with bristled burr,
a tear-out tyrant's leap,
It hissed in sap and shuddered grrr—
skreek-skack, splinter-peep!

He danced the bevel, rolled the wrist,
he let the gougehead weep;
He skated edges, skew and twist—
fishtail gouge sweep!

Flip-flooted, with a whittle-whirl,
he scooped the burl to sleep,
He tamed the snarl to curlicurl—
kerf-kiss, curl-and-keep.

The Splintergrim grew soft and small,
a friendly whittle-beep;
It nested in a spiral stall,
a ribboned, shining sleep.

Then benchlight waned to walnut dusk,
and silence padded deep,
The grainwind took its hush and husk—
fishtail gouge sweep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Letter Kept in a Cedar Box

Cedar-gloam the cupboard’s hush,
and papermotes went muff and mox;
the inkwind made a murmur-slush
round letter kept in a cedar box.

“Beware the Whisperglyph, my sprout—
its loops that lean, its curls that coax!
Beware the seal that sighs without,
the cedar-hearted hoax!
Beware the Maybe-Morrow moth,
and shun the Sorrow-fox!”

He gripped his creaser-knife so keen,
the sever-slice of pearl and brass;
he paced by boards of varnish-green
and let his thinkings pass,
then tipped the lid with careful thumb
and breathed the cedarn gas.

From folded fold a hush uncoiled—
a scripty shape with lampblack glare;
its letterbones went riffling wild,
its breath said, “Were you? Are?”
It sworled and swuffled through the grain,
a cursive-colder air.

Zip-zap went crease and skitter-crack—
the paperblade made crinkle-sparks;
he parried loops and blotted back
the lash of inky arcs.
He cleft the ribbon-knot in two
and hushed the cursive larks.

Back through the cedar-scent he strode,
with slip and seal and severed locks.
“O rapture-roon! Caroola-ode!”
they cried, and thumped the box.
He loosed the clocks of ink and time
and read the long-lost talks.

Cedar-gloam the cupboards stay,
and papermotes go muff and mox;
yet ever in the grain you may
hear letters pace their box.

info.topic: letter kept in a cedar box

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "Morse straight key click". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Morse Straight Key Click

When twillick fell, the wirelines sang
Down pole and porcelain brick;
The spark-lamps purred, the meters rang
To Morse straight key click.

The steam of midnight tea went curled,
The logbook smudged with ink;
And out across the copper world
There tipt and topp’d the clink.

"Keep far," said old Bell-Whickery,
"From Klickle-Klack the Slick;
It bites your dash, it nips your ee,
That Morse straight key click.

"The Ditty-Dah will dumble-wrung
Your tangle-box and wick;
It eats your hush with iron tongue
And stabs the hours tick."

I took my oak-hand sounder-rod,
My cans with velvet thick,
And paced the ties where pole-feet trod
For Morse straight key click.

Through bramble-wire and stormy wheeze,
Past frost that bit and pricked,
I felt along the humming breeze
A dit and dah up-pricked.

There flared the Blinker-Banshee bright,
Its beak like polished pick;
It pecked the dusk in crumbs of light—
A Morse straight key click.

"Ho! hush you, twitchy Klincher-gnat,"
I cried with tongue-quick trick;
I matched its taps with tittle-tat
Of dah and dapper dit.

We wrangled beats and juggled bars,
We tangled tap to tick,
Till cadence tamed its nickel snares
And cooled the crackling slick.

Then soft it sat on coil and rail,
A mild and mindful nick;
It sang my name in tinny hail
With Morse straight key click.

Home-bent I strode; the old man spun
His pipe in somber wick:
"Well played, my kit! The line is won
From Morse straight key click!"

Now twillick falls; the wirelines purr
By pole and porcelain brick;
The night is tame, the messages stir
In Morse straight key click.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fiddle rosin dust". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Fiddle Rosin Dust

At twilfer-turn the skreely bows
went scritch and scroodle through the gust;
All linty-lush the case-lid glows,
with fiddle rosin dust.

"Take heed," quoth Gram, "the Rosinwraith—
that rasping gloom of grit and gust;
Shun Bowgnash, with its gummy scathe,
and sticky clots of dust."

He grasped his catgut-braided brand,
and tightened pegs with nip and thrust;
He stalked into the fiddler’s land
to beard the rosin dust.

He brooded by the music stand,
while paper-ghosts went flit and gust;
His ear grew long as silence spanned
for fiddle rosin dust.

And o! from casewood breathed a hiss—
a skrindle-squeal, a powdery gust;
The Rosinwraith, with gritling kiss,
came scumbling out in dust.

He lifted high the horsehair brand,
it sang a bray of bite and thrust;
Skree-krack! it leapt from hand to hand,
and severed grit from dust.

He bagged the ghost in linen-tight,
and tamped the powder’s skirling gust;
He strode to Gram in candlelight,
still snowed with rosin dust.

"O bravosome!" the Gramkin cried;
"Fine scriddle-lad! Come sup and crust!"
They jigged and japed from side to side,
while shimmering rose the dust.

At twilfer-turn the skreely bows
go scritch and scroodle through the gust;
Now warm the case-lid amber glows—
and settles rosin dust.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Plane Iron Camber

'Twas shavings-tide, and slithery grains
Did skitter-scrim across the wood;
All wispy were the bench-top planes,
And mumpish knots there stood.

"Attend the plane-iron camber, boy—
Its curvèd smile, its tempered thread;
It yields you curls of whisping joy,
Or rends the grain to shred.

"Befend the snarlèd tear-out things—
The splutching swales of knot and fleck;
Beware the sneery bevel-kings,
The chattery throat-wreck."

He trued his edge on stropstone green,
He lapped it long on oil and slate;
He honed until the steel grew keen,
Then bided grain and fate.

He perched beside the bench-dog bite,
And peered along the board so wide;
When snorfling through the figure-light
The Ragged Grain did glide.

Zip-zip! skreek-skreak! the camber sang—
It kissed, it skimmed, it broke the fray;
Down knurly hills the shavings sprang,
And tear-out slunk away.

He planed it smooth—the ragged snare—
And skirlumping home he strode at length:
"O scrumbious day! we plane the air!"
He whooped with benchman's strength.

And shavings-tide, with slithery grains,
Still witter-wattles through the wood;
Now merry hum the camber-planes,
Where tear-out once had stood.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Orin Bell Hum

When murkle fell, the sallow snigs
went thrindle through the slum;
The snaggle ferns in tassel wigs
heard Orin-Bell go hum.

“Mind well the Orin-Bell,” quoth Pryn,
“that hums by bog and brum;
Its honey-iron, hollow din
will thrum your wits to crumb.”

He grasped his whittle-whattle glaive
with clindy-knotted thumb;
He sought the quag where moonmoths wave—
to track the bell-born hum.

And as he stood in shaddered think,
beside the flindered plumb,
Down bendled through the bracken brink
the Orin-Bell did come.

It shone with brazen tallow-face,
its lipless smile was numb;
Its ribs were rings, its feet were lace;
it sang a thunder-hum.

Click-clack! the whittle-whattle sped,
kerang! kerim! kerum!
He feinted left; it reared its head
and boomed a brassy hum.

He cleft the clapper from its ring,
untethered bell from strum;
It fell in coils, a slackened thing—
no more the moorlands hum.

He lolloped home o’er bog and bridge,
through snig and snag and scum;
“Ha! Hurralow!” cried Grimble Fridge,
“thou’st stilled the Orin-hum!”

When murkle falls, the sallow snigs
still thrindle through the slum;
The snaggle ferns in tassel wigs
remember not that hum.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quenching Brine Hiss

’Twas gloam-o’-tide; the kelpish reeds
Did snurl and snitter by the scar;
And hush! along the shingle-beds
Came quenching brine hiss from afar.

“Beware the Brinehiss, spratling boy!
The gulping gale, the salt-snake’s kiss!
Beware the dribble-draggle buoy,
And shun the quenching brine hiss!”

He gripped his corrugraven spear,
His barnacled and brackish blade;
He trod the mizzled pier in fear,
Where gull-winds gnash and ropes are frayed.

He stilled beside the splintered stake,
Where lighthouse-ghosts go peal and miss,
And through the fog, all flake on flake,
He heard the quenching brine hiss.

Then skreeling from the wrinkled brine
It slumped—an urchin-armored maw;
Its lantern-eyes like kelper-shine,
Its fins went rasp and clench and gnaw.

One tide-long beat—he set his heel
And swung a swash across the mist;
There came a clapper, cleave, and peal—
And hushed the quenching brine hiss.

“O brinebright day! Hullo, hurrah!”
Cried he, with foam about his wrist.
They capered home to kettle-char,
While far-off died the brine’s last hiss.

Now gloam-o’-tide; the kelpish reeds
Do snurl and snitter by the scar;
The shingle hushes all its beads—
No quenching brine hiss from afar.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Badger Knot Bloom

At duskling hour the bristled brooms
did twirl and titter through the glen;
The nubbled hedges brewed their glooms,
and snudgebugs droned by fives and ten.

“Mind well,” croaked Patter-uncle Sprig,
“that bloom that badgers, sly and sheer;
Its whisker-vines in tricksy rig
will loop your legs and fog your ear.”

He raised his clip-snip pruning blade,
the hedgebright steel that hums and hums;
He donned his nettle-shadowed shade
and stepped among the thistle drums.

He paused beside the puddle-stone,
a-muddle in his mizzle mood;
Then rustle, snuffle, burr and groan
came creeping from the bramblewood—
and up it heaved through thorn and loom,
with whisk and petal, snout and plume:
all knotted tight in briary doom,
it was the badger knot bloom.

Flip-flap, clip-clap, the pruning sang;
kinked tendrils leapt to lace his knee;
He cleft the tangles fang by fang
and loosed their sour pollen free.

At last he nicked the knuckle-core,
the heart-knot of that bristled flower;
It sighed a swampish perfume-roar
and slumped to sleep its sapless hour.

He bounded home to Patter-kin—
“O scrumbulous day, tra-loo, tra-lay!”
They broom-banged pans in tinny din
and jigged the thyme along the day.

At duskling hour the bristled brooms
still twirl and titter through the glen;
The hedges nurse their gentle glooms,
and knots unbind, then bind again.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Nib Tine Micro‑Mesh

When gloam o’clock on parchment plain
Set quivers through the thresh,
The slither‑scrive and scratch‑and‑grain
Went murmur‑muddle‑fresh.

“Beware,” quoth Gran of Blotter Glen,
“The Skritchalope so brash!
Beware the Burr‑Begristle pen,
The gummy Gobble‑gash!

“Hold tight your patience, little scribe,
And still your inky thrash;
Take not the Snaggle‑stroke’s rude bribe—
Use nib tine micro‑mesh.

“For there are bites in brittle tines,
And bites that bite your text;
The Scumble‑Scurf that kinks your lines
Will snag the sayer next.”

I primed my pad of pearly grit,
My swarf‑soft polishing flesh;
With hushful hands I steadied it—
My nib tine micro‑mesh.

Through spooly stacks and ledger lanes
Came Scratchalope, a‑screech,
With raspish rasp and raggy manes
It clattered, clove, and breech.

We circled round the ink‑well’s rim—
It made a snarl‑ish swash;
I swirled it past the paper’s brim
With skritch‑skritch, swarf‑and‑wash.

I stroked along the singing steel,
Till roughling turned to hush;
The chatter‑snag forgot to squeal
And melted into plush.

Then hushabloom the letters flowed,
A velvet river’s rush;
Where once the ragged scrawl had towed,
Now streamed the silken gush.

Back home I bore the tempered gleam,
With joy‑jink, tip‑and‑tresh:
“O day of flow! O writing dream!
O nib tine micro‑mesh!”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Krenovian Plane Throat

Twilit were the shiver leaves,
They skirl and skitter through the grove;
All wisple were the ribbon sheaves,
And knot-born whispers wove.

“Beware the Krenovian Plane Throat,
Whose tight-lipped mouth makes silk of day!
Beware the Snipe and Tear-out’s note,
And shun the Splinter’s bray!”

He took his bevel-brilling blade,
Cap-iron snug and sole a-true;
He honed and honed—mirror-laid—
Then strode the grainward blue.

He perched upon the benching stump,
In mullish mood he chewed his plan;
When hush-and-hither, swarf and thump,
Came slivering through the span—

The Plane Throat through the burlwood came,
Its mouth a moon-thin nip so slight;
It sipped the air and shaved the name
From bark with whisper-bite.

Skreek-skrak! The bevel met its maw;
The tote-hand burned, the wedge-heart rang!
Shree-shraw! along the sole and saw,
The irons sang and sang.

He skewed, he set—a cunning set—
And drove a true, untearing stroke;
The plane-thin hush grew thinner yet,
And not a splinter broke.

“And hast thou tamed the Plane Throat then?
Come to my arms, my shavings boy!
O gladsome day! O chisel-when!”
He jigged in planer joy.

Twilit are the shiver leaves,
They skirl and skittle through the grove;
All wisple go the ribbon sheaves,
And knot-born whispers wove.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Rain on a Tin Roof

Bing-bang the plitter-platter plays,
Along the winkled roof;
The sky is full of slinky grays
That drum their drippy proof.

“Beware the Guttersnoggle, child!
The grebble drains that grin!
Beware the Rattleshade, so wild,
That tambours on the tin!”

He grabbed his clinkerspoon and pan
And laced his jingly boot;
He tiptoe-crept, a careful man,
To catch the caperoot.

From stovepipe throat a Nimble-Din,
With plick and plock and ping,
Came skirring down the sheeted tin,
A slicker-snickering thing.

He set the pail where driplets bit—
Plunk-ploon!—beneath the beam;
The Rumble-rain, by cunning wit,
Kept time like kettle-dream.

“O splendor-splash!” the Kettle cried,
“O plunkantee, plunkatee!
Come warm your toes in drimsy pride,
And sip a snoodel tea.”

Bing-bang the plitter-platter plays,
Along the winkled roof;
Yet now it jigs in twinkly ways,
Not thunder’s thudding proof.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sencha kyusu drip". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sencha Kyusu Drip

At brimglow, when the flutterleaves
Went whisper-wind in steeping sweep,
The kettle purred its thistlebreath,
And the side-hand spout went weep.

“Take heed,” quoth Gramp of teawise brow,
“Of Scaldgrawl’s hiss and tannin lip!
There skulk the Sludge-and-Stinglings now—
And shun the scorchy sip.

Keep water cool as moonlit glass,
Let sevened sevens lightly slip;
No boil-bark dare your leaves harass—
Sencha kyusu drip.”

He took his kyusu, side-hand neat,
A sievey-mesh and leaf-wise lip;
He cradled jade within its belly,
And breathed, “sencha kyusu drip.”

Through steamwraith lanes the Scaldgrawl crept,
All crackle-scaled and bitter-gripped;
It slurped the cups and singed the air,
And gloated, scorchily equipped.

In hush of kettles, cool and keen,
He swirled a lunar-cooling slip;
The beast unbristled, scale by scale,
At the sencha kyusu drip.

A thread of springlike grassy green
Went twining from the spout’s soft tip;
The Scaldgrawl shrank to fragrant hush
And loosed its brangly grip.

He bore the cup with leafbright grin;
Old Gramp did jig and clatter-hip:
“O mellow morn of dew-sweet brew!
O tink-and-taste-and-sip!”

At brimglow, when the flutterleaves
Go whisper-wind in steeping sweep,
The kettle purrs its thistlebreath,
And quieted spouts don’t weep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
I can’t write in Lewis Carroll’s exact style, but here’s an original, playful nonsense poem capturing a whimsical, portmanteau-rich vibe.

Split‑Grade Enlarger Burn

Beneath the amberlume they churn,
The traylings slosh and yearn;
The silverseed begins to learn
The split‑grade enlarger burn.

“Take heed,” croaked old Developer,
“Of flarefang’s hiss and purr;
Mind dodgewraith masks that twist and turn,
And grainwolves in the blur.”

I gripped my filterfingers tight,
My contrast-wands of light,
A cardblade cut from velvet dark,
A teststrip-shield of night.

From bellows-throat there spilled a flare,
A scorch-fox from the air;
It padded over easel-fern—
The Burnling of the Lair.

We jittered in a shadow duel,
By tongs and tray and rule;
I swept a circle, slow and stern,
And burned it, cool by cool.

The selenium winds began to sing,
The silvered edges ring;
I split the grades from soft to firm,
And trimmed the Burnling’s sting.

Back to the elder, splash by tray,
I bore the print, half-gray;
He sniffed the fumes and smiled to learn
The dawn from soot and clay.

O silverbright, the clothespins clacked,
The safelight softly cracked;
We hung the dream to drip and turn—
Split‑grade enlarger burn.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Kiridashi Scribe-Line

At gloam o’gleg the shavings skree,
The whittle-winds entwine;
Slim sliver-sprites went whirrliglee,
Down kiridashi scribe line.

“Mark well,” quoth elder Carverkin,
“That edge of whisper-fine;
Beware the Grainwight’s grin within
The kiridashi scribe line.”

He took his brash unbending blade,
The square, the rule, the sign;
And sought the bench where lamplights laid
A moon upon the line.

He bided where the grain ran deep,
By knurl and knot design;
Then, creeplish, from the planed-out sweep,
It nuzzled down the line.

Its eyelets winked with measure-marks,
Its scales of steelpine shine;
A silk-edged hiss uncoiled the darks—
O kiridashi scribe line!

He raised his blade to counter-skim,
He leapt in brace and bind;
Skritch-scrack! went edge on edge with him,
They ribboned chips behind.

Through twist of knot and bevel’s bend,
He feinted true and fine;
And split the whisper to its end,
Unzipping down the line.

He swung a braid of curls to show,
A glinting, grain-laced vine;
“At last!” they cried, in sawdust snow,
“You’ve gentled Scribe-Edge Line!”

At gloam o’gleg the benches gleam,
And hush the shopwinds’ whine;
All chiplets dream a measured dream
Along kiridashi scribe line.
